user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count:
```c
int
mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count (void)
{
  int res;

#if defined(__linux__) || defined(__GLIBC__)
  /* On Linux kernel try first 'sched_getaffinity()' as it should be
     the native API.
     Also try it first on other kernels if Glibc is used. */
  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;

  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_cpuset_getaffinity_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;
#else  /* ! __linux__ && ! __GLIBC__ */
  /* On non-Linux kernels 'cpuset_getaffinity()' could be the native API,
     while 'sched_getaffinity()' could be implemented in compatibility layer. */
  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_cpuset_getaffinity_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;

  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;
#endif /* ! __linux__ && ! __GLIBC__ */

  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_np_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;

  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_w32_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;

  return -1;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only elements in this function that may rely on compiler/implementation-provided language extensions are the use of predefined/implementation macros (__linux__, __GLIBC__) in the preprocessor conditional. Other parts of the code are standard C constructs (function definition, local variable, if tests, return statements, function calls, #endif) and do not use compiler language extensions. The calls to platform-specific APIs (sched_getaffinity, cpuset_getaffinity, *_np, w32 functions) are platform/library-specific symbols, not language/compiler extensions documented as such; they should be reviewed for portability or API conformance but are outside the scope of MISRA C Rule 1.2 (language extensions). The identifier naming (including trailing underscores in helper function names) are user-defined identifiers and not compiler extensions. Therefore no other fragments need to be investigated for Rule 1.2.
